title: Boy, 2, nearly died after being savaged by venomous snake
text:
Atlas Johnson was bitten by a copperhead snake on Wednesday in Horry County, South Carolina. (Picture: WMBF)

A two-year-old boy nearly died after he was bitten by a highly venomous snake.

Atlas Johnson’s parents are now just thankful their son is alive after he was attacked by a copperhead snake last week in Horry County, South Carolina.

The toddler’s father, Gregory Johnson, told WMBF: ‘Wednesday night, we were walking down the driveway and we were walking to the car and I stepped off the concrete first and as soon as Atlas stepped off behind me he got bit by a snake right here.’

‘Struck him in the back of the leg and I handed him off to his mother and we saw in the light two fang marks.’

Gregory said he caught a glimpse of the snake and realized it was a copperhead, so he and Atlas’s mother, Taylor Gibson, rushed the boy to the Conway Medical Center.

Atlas was monitored for four hours by doctors who sent him home with Benadryl – but the next morning, Atlas’s leg had swollen and begun turning black so his parent’s took him back to the hospital.

Gibson said: ‘The staff at the hospital and MUSC, they came up with a plan that they were going to start giving the Crofab and they asked if we were okay with that and we said “Yeah, I want my little boy here.”‘

Crofab is an anti-venom used to treat snake bites. Atlas was given the medication twice over the following day.

His mother said: ‘The next morning his foot looked amazing compared to it being black when we were at the hospital.’

Pictures taken Thursday show how quickly the snake venom caused the tissue on Atlas’s leg to deteriorate. While copperhead bites are not usually fatal for adults, they are especially dangerous for children.

Copperhead snakes are named after their reddish or golden tan color. They are not usually aggressive, but are more likely to bite when people unknowingly step on or near them. (Picture: CDC)

By Monday, the discoloring on Atlas’s leg was reduced, but it was still present and gave the boy’s leg a bruised, black-and-blue hue.

Atlas is expected to make a full recovery, but the incident left his parents nervous about letting their son out of their sight.

‘I’m still terrified to let him out in the grass.

‘I’m not comfortable with him going to play yet, but who would?

‘Because even though he (Atlas’s father) was one step ahead of him and I was one step behind him, we couldn’t stop it,’ Gibson said.

Atlas’s foot and leg stopped swelling and the bruising was reduced after doctors administered Cofab (Picture: WMBF)

The horrific encounter with the copperhead snake has not seemed to slow Atlas down though.

He was running around the house on Monday, but his parents hope this serves a lesson to others.

‘It’s just, you never know. you should, and if they get in the playsets, in the cars, in the toys.

‘Right now, I’m looking in the area under our porch because he could get under our ledge,’ Gibson said.
description: Atlas Johnson, 2, was bitten by a copperhead snake last week and was rushed to the hospital in Horry County, South Carolina.
